FRESHMEN APPOINT COMMITTEE
TO SELECT CLASS PIN.

At a meeting of the Freshman
Class last Tuesday, President
Wood appointed Markell, Knecht,
Lovell and Cotton as members of
a committee to select a class pin.
At the same meeting it was decided to make up a class fund of
25 cents per person to defray expenses until next year. Those who
have had any experience in debating were urged to come out for
the freshman-sophomore debate,
the date of which has not been
set.
Y. M. C. A. Notice.

C
TRADE

and student members. The meeting was one that augured well for
the future of the Circle. Robert
Hoffman, recently returned to the
University, was initiated into the
society.
Among the many important
items discussed, was the "prep"
school campaign which the Omicron Delta Kappa has launched.
This is an idea instituted by this
Circle as a means of putting before the future college men\now at
the "prep" schools in Maryland, in
a clear and straight-forward manner, the excellent opportunities
that Johns Hopkins offers. Already letters have been sent the
high schools concerning the sending of Hopkins speakers to their
institutions, and many favorable
replies have been received.
To carry out this plan, the Circle has appointed G. S. Cattanach,
C. T. Leber and A. B. Coleman
to present to the "prep" school
students in the State the benefits
that may be derived at Hopkins.
Several trips will be made this
spring to different parts of the
State, including the Eastern
Shore and Western Maryland.
At the meeting, Captain Guild
expressed his appreciation of the
excellent work done by the Omicron Delta Kappa in connection
with the R. 0. T. C. enrollment.
The meeting adjourned to meet
again on April 15.

Capt. C. W. Maxson, U. S. Army,
will lecture on Thursday, April 3,
at 1.15 o'clock. Captain Maxson
was three times captured by the
Germans, twice made daring escapes, but after his third capture
was a prisoner of war in Camp
Rastaat, Baden, Germany, for
seven months. He will tell of his
thrilling experiences.

IN MEMORIAM
K. F. S.

Purples and crimson fleck the Iliad's roll,
But Homer's sunlight has no tinge of red
Whene'er it plays on Nestor's good grey head,
His fluent wisdom, and his wassail bowl.
But when we ope the Odyssean scroll,
And share the banquet the brave Pylian spread,
One form we miss—Antilochos is dead—
And human sorrows touch the human soul.
- estor has become too cheap,
The title N
And so I fretted when the lapse of years
Brought me the name that many dolts have borne;
But I have learned to weep with them that weep,
And understand old Nes or's ceaseless tears,
For I have an Antiloch)s to mourn.
—Basil Lanneau Gildersleeve.
(Tribute to Prof. Kirby Flower Smith in the Alumni Magazine.)

APRIL 1, 1919

A Fitting Memorial.
Colleges all over the country
are launching vigorous memorial
fund campaigns in order to perpetuate the memory of their sons
who served.
Many • different
forms of memorials are being
considered, among them buildings,
monuments, athletic fields and endowment funds. At Lehigh, for
example, the campaign is for a
memorial administration building and has been started with
r.lnarkable success, $1;100,000 Ioning been coirtributed by fifty men.
We hope that Hopkins will at
le 1st equal this flying start in her
drive for a memorial fund. The
plans are under discussion, and
yet no definite information
ie
has been given out, but it is certain that the memorial will assume the form of a handsome
and capacious dormitory, one of
the University's pressing needs.
It is particularly fitting that
the hnig-iftoposed dormitory has
been chosen to commemorate the
service of Hopkins men to their
country. They, by their deeds,
have displayed the true Hopkins
spirit; and now the (lormitory,
their memorial, will indeed be a
cradle of the same spirit. The
lack of dormitories has long been
regarded as a serious handicap to
Hopkins athletics and other
forms of activities—to Hopkins

of the walk, and trampled with
new spleen. Four other tramplers followed them, and still another four; and thick and fast
they crossed the grass, and more
and more and more; all eager
now to make a path where none
had been before. "But wait a
bit!" the grass blades cried, "before you have your treat. Just
let us start, 'tis hard enough—
we earnestly entreat—to grow beneath your tread, you are so
heavy on your feet!" The tramplers, all undaunted, replied,
"That's not the trick. The idea
is to get you young and t:eat
you rough so quick, you'll all be
dead before you even know that
you are sick." They trampled till
the sun went down; then crying,
-We're some class!" they started
'cross the lawn, but see—there
was no lawn to pass! And this
was scarcely odd because there
wasn't any grass.

wife asked him where he had been
away from home all that time,
and he told her a whale had swallowed him.—Baltimore American.

Sects Should Remain Distinct But Should
Lay Most Stress on Fundamentals
Common to All—Churches Must
Become Democratized.

A resolution was passed at a
recent senior executive committee
meeting recommending that the
Senior Class at Syracuse University establish a Memorial Endowment Fund in the form of a life
insurance policy of $1,000 to be
taken out by each member, with

plan is being forwarded with the

$15,000,000 was left to the uni- endowment fund, but also a suitversity upon the death of John able and lasting memorial to the

Connecticut College has abandoned the "blacklist." Students
will be permitted to hold office
and to participate in athletics
without academic restrictions, the
good judgment and honor of each
student being the only test in each
case.

In speaking on "The Fundamental Conceptions in a Religion
for the New Democracy," at the
open forum last Thursday Rabbi
M. S. Lazaron emphasized the
need of more stress on the fundamentals of religion, and the necessity of realizing that the minor
differences of the sects are merely
man-made. Forms and ceremonies, said the speaker, in all religions should be considered as
but the garments in which we
wrap the sacred heritage of the
fundamentals of religion. All
should be tolerant of any garments in which others ,wish to
wrap their own heritage, as long
as the garments themselves are
not made the main thing. Religion has to change at this time,
when the whole economic and political life is changing under the
influence of the new spirit of
human brotherhood.
Rabbi Lazaron believes that
though the different denominations should lay most emphasis
upon the fundamentals, which
they have in common; nevertheless, they should be kept distinct
in their forms and ceremonies.
The forms and ceremonies are to
be interpreted into their deeper
meaning, but different forms will
appeal most strongly to people of
different mental make-ups; so, for
tie benefit of the greatest number, the denominations should remain distinct from each other.
The _economic and the industrial order are becoming democracized. So must the church
and synagogue. The place where
a man sits ought not to be decided by the size of his pocketbook and church contributions,
said Dr. Lazaron. The pulpit
should be open to people of all
views—it should be a forum for
truth.
In speaking of the needed
changes in theology, Rabbi Lazarm), emphatically denounced the
orthodox division of all the
world into the "saved" and the
"damned," according to whether
or not they believed certain dogmas, This division comes, he
said, from "a culturistic religious
philosophy." No one can say that
another will be damned, because
no religion, and no person, has
the whole truth. Jesus of Nazareth, said the Rabbi, has been
one-sidedly interpreted, and we
are in great need of a more adequate and truer interpretation of
Jesus' teaching.
Jesus showed in his life and in
his teaching, Dr. Rosenau stated,
the spirit of the older Jewish
prophets. He taught a doctrine
of love which has been converted
into a doctrine of molly-coddlism
and pacifism. The active Jesus,
the Jesus who raised his arm

FRESHMEN APPOINT COMMITTEE
TO SELECT CLASS PIN.

At a meeting of the Freshman
Class last Tuesday, President
Wood appointed Markell, Knecht,
Lovell and Cotton as members of
a committee to select a class pin.
At the same meeting it was decided to make up a class fund of
25 cents per person to defray expenses until next year. Those who
have had any experience in debating were urged to come out for
the freshman-sophomore debate,
the date of which has not been
set.
Y. M. C. A. Notice.

C
TRADE

and student members. The meeting was one that augured well for
the future of the Circle. Robert
Hoffman, recently returned to the
University, was initiated into the
society.
Among the many important
items discussed, was the "prep"
school campaign which the Omicron Delta Kappa has launched.
This is an idea instituted by this
Circle as a means of putting before the future college men\now at
the "prep" schools in Maryland, in
a clear and straight-forward manner, the excellent opportunities
that Johns Hopkins offers. Already letters have been sent the
high schools concerning the sending of Hopkins speakers to their
institutions, and many favorable
replies have been received.
To carry out this plan, the Circle has appointed G. S. Cattanach,
C. T. Leber and A. B. Coleman
to present to the "prep" school
students in the State the benefits
that may be derived at Hopkins.
Several trips will be made this
spring to different parts of the
State, including the Eastern
Shore and Western Maryland.
At the meeting, Captain Guild
expressed his appreciation of the
excellent work done by the Omicron Delta Kappa in connection
with the R. 0. T. C. enrollment.
The meeting adjourned to meet
again on April 15.

Capt. C. W. Maxson, U. S. Army,
will lecture on Thursday, April 3,
at 1.15 o'clock. Captain Maxson
was three times captured by the
Germans, twice made daring escapes, but after his third capture
was a prisoner of war in Camp
Rastaat, Baden, Germany, for
seven months. He will tell of his
thrilling experiences.

Whene'er it plays on Nestor's good grey head,
His fluent wisdom, and his wassail bowl.
But when we ope the Odyssean scroll,
And share the banquet the brave Pylian spread,
One form we miss—Antilochos is dead—
And human sorrows touch the human soul.

Brought me the name that many dolts have borne;

And understand old Nes or's ceaseless tears,
For I have an Antiloch)s to mourn.
—Basil Lanneau Gildersleeve.

APRIL 1, 1919

A Fitting Memorial.
Colleges all over the country
are launching vigorous memorial
fund campaigns in order to perpetuate the memory of their sons
who served.
Many • different
forms of memorials are being
considered, among them buildings,
monuments, athletic fields and endowment funds. At Lehigh, for
example, the campaign is for a
memorial administration building and has been started with
r.lnarkable success, $1;100,000 Ioning been coirtributed by fifty men.
We hope that Hopkins will at
le 1st equal this flying start in her
drive for a memorial fund. The
plans are under discussion, and
yet no definite information
ie
has been given out, but it is certain that the memorial will assume the form of a handsome
and capacious dormitory, one of
the University's pressing needs.
It is particularly fitting that
the hnig-iftoposed dormitory has
been chosen to commemorate the
service of Hopkins men to their
country. They, by their deeds,
have displayed the true Hopkins
spirit; and now the (lormitory,
their memorial, will indeed be a
cradle of the same spirit. The
lack of dormitories has long been
regarded as a serious handicap to
Hopkins athletics and other
forms of activities—to Hopkins

let us start, 'tis hard enough—
we earnestly entreat—to grow beneath your tread, you are so

'cross the lawn, but see—there
was no lawn to pass! And this
was scarcely odd because there
wasn't any grass.

Sects Should Remain Distinct But Should
Lay Most Stress on Fundamentals
Common to All—Churches Must
Become Democratized.

A resolution was passed at a
recent senior executive committee
meeting recommending that the
Senior Class at Syracuse University establish a Memorial Endowment Fund in the form of a life
insurance policy of $1,000 to be
taken out by each member, with

plan is being forwarded with the

$15,000,000 was left to the uni- endowment fund, but also a suitversity upon the death of John able and lasting memorial to the

Connecticut College has abandoned the "blacklist." Students
will be permitted to hold office
and to participate in athletics
without academic restrictions, the
good judgment and honor of each
student being the only test in each
case.

In speaking on "The Fundamental Conceptions in a Religion
for the New Democracy," at the
open forum last Thursday Rabbi
M. S. Lazaron emphasized the
need of more stress on the fundamentals of religion, and the necessity of realizing that the minor
differences of the sects are merely
man-made. Forms and ceremonies, said the speaker, in all religions should be considered as
but the garments in which we
wrap the sacred heritage of the
fundamentals of religion. All
should be tolerant of any garments in which others ,wish to
wrap their own heritage, as long
as the garments themselves are
not made the main thing. Religion has to change at this time,
when the whole economic and political life is changing under the
influence of the new spirit of
human brotherhood.
Rabbi Lazaron believes that
though the different denominations should lay most emphasis
upon the fundamentals, which
they have in common; nevertheless, they should be kept distinct
in their forms and ceremonies.
The forms and ceremonies are to
be interpreted into their deeper
meaning, but different forms will
appeal most strongly to people of
different mental make-ups; so, for
tie benefit of the greatest number, the denominations should remain distinct from each other.
The _economic and the industrial order are becoming democracized. So must the church
and synagogue. The place where
a man sits ought not to be decided by the size of his pocketbook and church contributions,
said Dr. Lazaron. The pulpit
should be open to people of all
views—it should be a forum for
truth.
In speaking of the needed
changes in theology, Rabbi Lazarm), emphatically denounced the
orthodox division of all the
world into the "saved" and the
"damned," according to whether
or not they believed certain dogmas, This division comes, he
said, from "a culturistic religious
philosophy." No one can say that
another will be damned, because
no religion, and no person, has
the whole truth. Jesus of Nazareth, said the Rabbi, has been
one-sidedly interpreted, and we
are in great need of a more adequate and truer interpretation of
Jesus' teaching.
Jesus showed in his life and in
his teaching, Dr. Rosenau stated,
the spirit of the older Jewish
prophets. He taught a doctrine
of love which has been converted
into a doctrine of molly-coddlism
and pacifism. The active Jesus,
the Jesus who raised his arm
